title: Netflix to acquire Warner Bros studio and streaming business for $72 billion
text:
Netflix has struck a deal with Warner Bros Discovery to buy the legacy Hollywood giant's studio and streaming business for $US72 billion ($108 billion).

The acquisition, announced overnight, would bring two of the industry's biggest players in film and TV under one roof. Beyond its namesake television and motion picture division, Warner owns HBO Max and DC Studios. And Netflix has risen to dominance as a household name ubiquitous to on-demand content, while building its own production arm to release popular titles like Stranger Things and Squid Game .

The cash and stock deal is valued at $US27.75 per Warner share, giving it a total enterprise value of approximately $US82.7 billion ($124.55 billion). The transaction is expected to close after Warner separates its Discovery Global cable operations into a new publicly-traded company in the third quarter of 2026.

This image released by Warner Bros Pictures shows Leonardo DiCaprio in a scene from One Battle After Another. (AP)

Shares of Warner Bros rose nearly 3 per cent in premarket trading while shares of Netflix and Paramount fell more than 2 per cent.

Gaining Warner's legacy studios would mark a notable shift for Netflix's current movie theatre footprint. Under the proposed acquisition Netflix has promised to continue theatrical releases for Warner's studio films — honouring Warner's contractual agreements for movie releases.

Netflix has kept most of its original content within its core online platform. But there have been a few exceptions, such as limited theatre screenings of a KPop Demon Hunters sing-a-long and its coming Stranger Things series finale.

As recently as October — when Warner signalled that it was open to a potential sale of its business — Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos reiterated on an earnings call that the company had been "very clear in the past that we have no interest in owning legacy media networks" and that there was "no change there".

"We believe that we can be and we will be choosy," Sarandos said at the time, without fully ruling out a potential bid for Warner.

READ MORE: Tributes to woman killed by her own dog in South Australian home ﻿

Netflix has struck a deal with Warner Bros Discovery to buy the legacy Hollywood giant's studio and streaming business for $US72 billion ($108 billion). (AP)

Friday's announcement arrives after a monthslong bidding war for Warner Bros Discovery. Rumours of interest from Netflix, as well as NBC owner Comcast, started bubbling up in the northern hemisphere autumn. But Skydance-owned Paramount, which completed its own $US8 billion merger in August, had also reportedly made several all-cash offers backed heavily by CEO David Ellison's family.

title: Music festivals keep getting canned. Nearly half of Aussies say this could fix it
text:
Exclusive: Thousands of Australians have been directly affected by the slew of music festival cancellations over the last 12 months, including Park Waves festival this week.

Now they're calling for more government investment in the scene, according to a nine.com.au reader poll.

More than 40 per cent of﻿ the ﻿434 readers surveyed agreed that federal and state governments should invest in Australia's live music industry to support festivals and prevent more cancellations in 2026.

"The government should support music the same way they support international sports such as tennis, golf and soccer," one told 9news.com.au.﻿

A further 39 per cent of readers confessed to being at least 'somewhat concerned' about the future of Australian music festivals in light of recent events.

Park Waves festival, scheduled for February 2026, was cancelled on Tuesday due to challenges including economic issues.

"Ultimately, the numbers no longer stack up," organisers said in a statement.

Changing Tides 2025 was canned, and Groovin' The Moo cancelled its 2024 shows and didn't return in 2025.

Falls Festival and Splendour in the Grass gave 2025 a miss as well.

Long-running festival Splendour in the Grass did not return in 2025. (Mark Metcalfe/Stringer/Getty)

Money is the biggest issue for most Australian music festivals, according to two Creative Australia reports on the sector.

Rising operational costs, a lack of available funding and grants, and insurance costs have made it challenging for organisers to finance festivals.

Australians' ticket buying habits have also changed, creating uncertainty for organisers.

Festival goers ages 18 to 24 are purchasing tickets at lower rates﻿ than pre-pandemic.

Patterns of later ticket buying are also continuing, creating additional costs and risks some organisers simply can't keep up with.

G﻿roovin' the Moo cancelled its 2024 shows and didn't return in 2025. (Instagram/Groovin the Moo)

But when organisers have to jack up ticket prices to cope with ﻿rising operational costs, it prices some Aussies out altogether.

"Music festival tickets are too expensive," one reader said.

Another added that it's not surprising that Aussies can't afford them when many struggle to afford groceries and rent.

A combined 61 per cent of nine.com.au readers said they were ﻿'not very concerned' or 'not concerned at all' about festival cancellations.

But only 30 per cent were opposed to government investment in Australia's live music industry to support festivals.

One reader said events like festivals need to be self-sustainable, rather than relying on government support.

About 28 per cent of readers were on the fence about government investment.

"I don't go to music festivals but some could bring more tourism to the country so perhaps the government should invest in some," one said.

Others were concerned about how it could affect taxpayers.﻿

"Festivals should be supported by the music labels to support our music industry, not be taxpayer-funded," said one.

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: Aussies paying more for private health insurance and getting less
text:
Australians are paying more for private health insurance and getting less for their money in return, a new report from the country's top doctors' advocacy group says.

The Australian Medical Association has released its latest Private Health Insurance Report Card, which found that consumers were abandoning gold-tier policies and questioning the value of other policies, while insurer profits piled up ever higher.

The AMA said the sector was in urgent need of reform, and President Dr Danielle McMullen renewed the call to establish an independent private health authority to drive that process.

People are paying more for private health insurance and receiving less, a new report says. (Getty)

"Australia's health system is valued for its mix of public and private healthcare, but both parts of the system are under increasing pressure," McMullen said.

"Public hospitals are struggling with a severe logjam crisis, which is pushing more patients towards the private sector.

"However, runaway insurance premiums, low value offerings and shady tactics like product phoenixing leave customers facing tough choices about the level of cover they can afford."

Cost of living pressures are seeing people drop gold-tier policies. (Nine)

Australians are paying more for private health insurance and getting less for their money in return, a new report from the country's top doctors' advocacy group says. (Getty)

The report card showed that every year since 2008, the growth of private health insurance premiums has outstripped inflation, health sector inflation, average weekly earnings and the indexation of the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS).

Between 2008 and 2024, premiums climbed more than 100 per cent, while MBS indexation – which was frozen for several years from 2013 – increased by less than 20 per cent.

The report card also shows that over the six years to June 2025, insurers increased benefits paid for in-hospital medical treatment by only 18.1 per cent, while sector profits grew by nearly 50 per cent over the same period.

READ MORE: Manhunt for prisoner who escaped from police at hospital ﻿

In 2024-2025, insurers returned 84.2 per cent of premiums to consumers as benefits, below the 2019 level of 88 per cent.

The AMA is calling on the federal government to mandate a 90 per cent return minimum for insurers.

"Of course, private health insurers must make a surplus to be sustainable, but it is clear they are holding out on Australians while recording significant profits each year," McMullen said.

The AMA is calling for major reform. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

"These insurers have ample capacity to increase the benefits paid to patients."

The report also found gold-tier policies are in decline as consumers face rising premiums and cost-of-living pressures.

Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020, the number of gold-tier policies have dropped by 360,000, despite the overall number of policies growing.

"These trends show that private health insurance is becoming less affordable for many Australians – and we are already seeing the drastic effects of this, with at least 14 private maternity units closing over the past five years," McMullen said.

"The need for a Private Health System Authority to better regulate the sector and drive long-term reform has never been more crucial. There are too many bodies involved in the regulation of private health – a single, independent authority would provide a unified and coherent approach."

title: Princess Kate celebrates community work at Christmas service
text:
The Prince and Princess of Wales have hosted an annual Christmas concert at Westminister Abbey in London to celebrate community work.

The royal family say the event, which Princess Catherine launched five years ago, offers them a chance to thank people across Britain for volunteering, raising funds for charity and supporting the vulnerable.

The service was held at Westminster Abbey. (Reuters: Aaron Chown)

Catherine, 43, last year completed a course of preventative chemotherapy to address an unspecified form of cancer.

She gave each guest a note highlighting how a "moment of listening" and "word of comfort" can make a difference to people's lives.

This is the fifth time the princess has held the service. (Reuters: Aaron Chown)

She and Prince William were pictured arriving at the service with their three children, George, 12, Charlotte, 10, and Louis, 7.

William was due to deliver a reading before 1,600 guests, along with actors Kate Winslet, Chiwetel Ejiofor and Joe Locke, as well as actor and comedian Babatunde Aléshé.

The royal family attended the service alongside 1,600 other guests. (Reuters: Chris Jackson)

"At a time when life can sometimes feel fragmented or uncertain, the Christmas season invites us to remember the power of reaching out to one another with generosity of heart, understanding and hope," Catherine wrote in her note.

The service was aimed at people of all faiths and those without faith, her Kensington Palace office said.

Westminster Abbey's choir was due to sing traditional Christmas carols, alongside performances of more contemporary music by Katie Melua.

The 'Together at Christmas' service will be broadcast on Britain's ITV television on Christmas Eve. (Reuters: Chris Jackson)

The "Together at Christmas" service will be broadcast on Britain's ITV television on Christmas Eve, while 15 community carol services supported by the couple's Royal Foundation charitable arm will be held across Britain during December.

title: After latest one-two punch, Australians will feel the pain in 2026
text:
An interest rate hike on Tuesday is a practical impossibility.

But if a growing number of forecasters are proved correct, it's a moot point, because one or more are on the way.

The reason is that Australia's inflation problem has not gone away and, by some measurements, is worsening.

Two official economic reports this week — the national accounts and the monthly household spending indicator — highlighted the key problem facing policymakers: too much money is chasing too few goods.

Up to now, nobody's figured out how to solve this problem.

Until it's solved, millions of mortgage borrowers will continue to pay the price.

A story RBA may not want to hear

Inflation fighters copped a one-two punch this week and both hits stung.

The national accounts for the September quarter, released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), showed the economy on a reasonably solid footing.

Australia's gross domestic product grew by 0.4 per cent in the September quarter, following growth of 0.7 per cent in the June quarter.

GDP's sting in the tail Australia's latest economic growth numbers show an economy in generally rude health, but that might result in a rude shock for mortgage borrowers earlier rather than later in 2026.

Essential household spending was up 1 per cent, driven by payments for banking and superannuation services, electricity and health.

Public investment grew by 3 per cent in the September quarter, rebounding from a 3.5 per cent fall in the June quarter.

A day later, the second punch came.

The ABS media release headline seemingly toying with the Reserve Bank: "Strong growth in goods lifts household spending".

"Discretionary spending surged this month led by goods as promotional events saw households spend more on clothing, footwear, furnishings and electronics following months of weaker spending in these categories," ABS head of business statistics Tom Lay said.

Millions of Australians clearly have money to spend.

Where from, you ask? Higher wages and investments income.

"The strong rise in gross disposable income was driven by COE [Compensation of Employees]," the ABS noted.

" Superannuation investment income also contributed to the rise, reflecting a strong performance in the domestic share market. "

The upshot of all this for the Reserve Bank is that there may be too much demand in the economy.

Australians are going shopping with the extra money in their pockets. (Pexels: Ron Lach)

An economy overwhelmed breeds inflation

When it rains too much, dams overflow.

When demand exceeds the capacity of an economy to meet it with supply, inflation rises.

Independent economist Chris Richardson has the hard numbers — extracted from the national accounts — to back this up.

He points out that although national production, or overall supply, lifted 2.1 per cent in the three months to September, demand rose 2.6 per cent.

"Worse still," he adds, "that 2.6 per cent was probably 2.8 per cent" because the ABS just announced it had to guess the speed of the rise in illegal tobacco.

"So, although our growth rate is disappointing, it is probably in line with what we're set to achieve over the longer term," he said.

It means "our dollar desires are pressing on the accelerator even though the clapped-out engine of the Australian economy is doing the best it can".

"That gap — too much money chasing too little stuff — is part of why price pressures are lingering," he said.

The solution? Productivity

The solution is to raise productivity, but it's happening at a snail's pace.

Quarterly growth in productivity has been oscillating between -0.5 per cent and 0.4 per cent for about 18 months.

In the three months to September this year it was 0.2 per cent.

The annual pace of productivity, however, lifted to slightly above the assumed rate of productivity the Reserve Bank uses in its forecasts.

Loading...

But, given the pace of demand appears to be increasing on the back of higher wages and investment incomes, productivity will also likely need to lift.

One positive development taken from the national accounts is the notable investment in data centres by business.

"This is likely due to firms looking to support growth in artificial intelligence and cloud computing capabilities," ABS head of National Account Grace Kim said.

This is a tangible example of a type of economic expansion.

And the ABS also noted real unit labour costs were -0.1 per cent in September quarter, which means each worker is now, on average, costing — a slightly more productive firm — less.

This reduces the pressure on business to pass costs onto customers.

Multiple rate hikes could be coming

But there is an inescapable fact: the economy, though only growing modestly, is buckling under the pressure.

It means demand needs to fall.

You could crash the property and stock markets, but few would agree to that.

And you can forget further hurting young renters by footing a higher cost of living.

That, rightly or wrongly, leaves mortgage borrowers to foot the bill for the productivity shortfall.

And they're now staring down the barrel of not just one, but potentially several interest rate hikes in 2026.

The state of the economy leaves RBA Governor Michele Bullock and her board with a narrow path forward. (ABC News: John Gunn)

"In our assessment, the detail of the data showed a much healthier consumer, hot housing market and elevated unit labour costs," investment firm Barrenjoey wrote in a note.

" We continue to expect rate hikes in May and August 2026. "

International bank HSBC is also onboard the multi-hike train.

"Growth is on an upswing, and, in our view, the economy is already operating at, or beyond, its 'speed limit'," chief economist Paul Bloxham wrote.

Rate hike could be here within months Hotter-than-expected inflation figures have caught many off guard and open the door for an RBA interest rate hike in 2026.

"We retain our view that the easing phase is done and shift our own central case to pencilling in hikes to begin from Q3 2026 (from Q1 2027 previously)."

Note the plural "hikes" used by Bloxham.

HSBC is also flirting with the idea of factoring in an RBA interest rate hike even sooner in the New Year, perhaps as early as February.

Market meltdown

What's also noteworthy is most, if not all, economists have placed a caveat on their interest rate hike predictions, warning of, as Paul Bloxham phrases it, "a negative global shock".

Next week, the Federal Reserve meets and hundreds of billions of dollars' worth of investment funds are betting on an interest rate cut.

You wouldn't want to be caught wrong-footed during next week's press conference.

At the same time Japanese interest rates are becoming more attractive by the hour to offshore investors — perhaps those without nerves of steel betting on American exceptionalism.

The economic year could be set to finish off with a bang.

title: Adelaide residents 'in the dark' over Gilbert Street development proposal
text:
Residents in Adelaide's CBD say planning laws have left them "in the dark" over a proposal to build a five-storey building, complete with a car stacker, that will overlook a childcare centre and an eco-living community.

They were first notified about the development proposal for 108 Gilbert Street in early 2024 through a leaflet drop from Adelaide City Council.

The Council Assessment Panel then received about 10 objections, and three people brought their concerns to its April 2024 meeting before the proposal was rejected.

The plan to boost Adelaide's CBD to 50,000 residents The Lord Mayor wants to nearly double the population of the CBD and North Adelaide by 2036.

About 12 months later, residents "informally" found out that an appeal had been made via the Environment, Resources and Development Court (ERDC).

A compulsory conference had been held behind closed doors, and planning permission for a compromised proposal later granted by the CAP.

"While the appellant, the developer, was allowed to submit a new proposal, the interested public were not informed of the court proceedings or directly informed of the judicial outcome," said Gilbert Street resident Peter Brady.

"It makes a mockery of the democratic court process."

Three storey-townhouses exist on the other side of Considine Place. (ABC Radio Adelaide: Malcolm Sutton)

The ERDC Act states that proceedings before the court must be heard in public.

But it also states that the court, where it considers reasons to be "sufficient", can give directions to exclude any person from a hearing, or require that that it be held in private, or prohibit or restrict the publication of evidence — or contents of any document — given to the court.

"Unless I am missing something, the whole system is at odds with itself. It appears to be a closed court while insisting in its documentation that it is truly open," Mr Brady said.

" You're in the dark. "

Deputy Lord Mayor Keiran Snape, who spoke to the ABC in his capacity as an independent candidate for Adelaide for next year's state election, is a former member of the CAP.

"Often the developers are unsuccessful that first time around, effectively told the reason why, and then they can go back and tweak those particular reasons and re-lodge — often without having to disclose to residents," he said.

"[This] is a difficult example of what happens."

A City of Adelaide spokesperson said it had expressed concern regarding "a reduction in third party appeal rights" following the state government's planning reforms in 2021.

"Council provided this feedback as part of its submission into the Planning System Implementation Review in January 2023," he said.

Abutting Christie Walk

The original proposal involved demolishing an existing building at the site, and building a six-level mixed-use building with an office at ground level and apartments above.

The CAP decided it constituted "excessive height", "overdevelopment with minimum site areas not satisfied", and there was a lack of adequate setbacks from the northern boundary abutting the Christie Walk eco-community.

Resident Geoff Schrader lives inside one of 27 dwellings at the village, which is used to demonstrate ecologically sustainable living in a city location, both through the buildings' construction and ongoing life span.

Geoff Schrader says the biggest issue with the development is associated car parking. (Supplied: Geoff Schrader)

He said the biggest problem with the proposal was car parking and how it would work when the building's access point will be Considine Place — a narrow laneway off Gilbert Street.

"It's how people get out of Christie Walk, and if there's a queue of cars trying to get into their car parks at the end of the day, or beginning of the day, that will be problematic," Mr Schrader said.

He said the lane also supported foot traffic from people heading to and from homeless shelters in and around Whitmore Square.

" The other issues are the fact it's kind of higher than the current height allowance for this portion of Gilbert Street, and it overlooks a childcare centre, so there are issues around child safety and so forth. "

The five-storey mixed-used building, if approved, will abut this childcare centre. (ABC Radio Adelaide: Malcolm Sutton)

The compromised proposal was presented to CAP at its January 29 2025 meeting, where it decided to grant planning consent.

The building height had been reduced to five levels, car parking spaces reduced from 28 to 19, and the set-back between the first and fourth levels and the northern boundary increased from 1 metre to more than 5m.

At ground level, however, from where the car stacker is believed to be located, it will be only a metre from Christie Walk buildings.

System 'allows for transparency'

A state government spokesperson said it was a matter for Adelaide City Council to communicate with "their residents about the decision they came to with the developer in the ERDC".

"The system allows for transparency, with publicly available documents uploaded to Plan SA at all times throughout the process per the legislative and policy frameworks," he said.

"Details of matters to be heard in the ERDC are publicly available through the case lists published daily on the Courts Administration Authority website."

The Christie Walk ecocity development was finished in December 2006. (ABC Radio Adelaide: Malcolm Sutton)

Mr Brady warned that a system that excluded third parties from appeal processes could be taken advantage of by developers.

"They know that the legislation is there, and indeed, everything that's been done so far here is due process and legal, but so what?" he said.

"I could be sitting here on my balcony and at the end of next year all of a sudden Whelan the Wrecker rolls in with a big ball, knocks the building down, and we're going, 'What?"

title: After the Rain reflects on Indigenous art's legacy while looking to future
text:
Tony Albert was an aspiring artist and arts worker when the inaugural National Indigenous Art Triennial opened almost 20 years ago.

Having travelled to Kamberri (Canberra) for it, Albert remembers standing in the National Gallery of Australia (NGA) and "knowing implicitly how important it was to be in that place, at that time with this institutional recognition of First Nations art".

Tony Albert is the first man to lead the National Indigenous Art Triennial. (Supplied: NGA)

Now the Girramay/Yidinji/Kuku-Yalanji man is one of the country's foremost contemporary artists and the artistic director of the latest triennial, which opens today at the NGA.

Albert's triennial is called After the Rain and reflects on matters of legacy as well as rebirth and renewal; on what rain washes away and what grows in its wake.

This is also the first artist-led iteration of the blockbuster exhibition.

"That's not symbolic; it's structural. Allowing an artist to lead shifts the model from representation to one of authorship," Albert tells ABC Radio National's Awaye!

"We have wonderful curators that are doing such a fantastic job and I never wanted to put myself in that position or to say that I believe I'm even in parallel to the incredible work they do."

Maŋgalili artist Naminapu Maymuru-White's Milŋiyawuy (Milky Way) depicts a Yolŋu understanding of the universe. (Supplied: NGA)

Instead he chose to use his role (and title) of artistic director to change the infrastructure and the ways in which institutions like the NGA work with Blakfullas.

"From the very instigation of [our] conversations we were making sure that the artists were heard, they were listened to, and I feel this triennial is the result of a different way of working," he says.

Creating seminal works

With only 10 featured projects, After the Rain might sound like a modest offering.

However, in paring back, Albert was able to provide his artists with more time, resources and care.

"Rather than try to fit many voices into a limited framework, After the Rain invests deeper into fewer projects. This allows artists to realise what may be their most seminal works of their career," Albert says.

One powerful example of this can be found in the immersive installation by Alair Pambegan, a Wik-Mungkan man from Aurukun and a cultural custodian of the flying fox story.

His own father had been part of that first triennial in 2007, and "featured as one of the 'big guns' — the major artists in the exhibition".

When Albert invited Pambegan to take part in After the Rain he wrote a letter asking he make his "most ambitious work to date", both on a cultural and artistic level.

Pambegan rose to the challenge.

His work, Kalben-aw story place of Wuku and Mukam the flying fox brothers, features more than 600 cylindrical painted wooden carvings suspended from the ceiling, as well as two ceremonial sculptures representing the brothers and the never-before-shown origins of that story.

Pambegan first worked with Albert on his first solo exhibition, in Sydney in 2017. (Supplied: NGA)

Pambegan's reinterpretation of such an important story (one that is explicitly about the consequences of our actions) also signals to Albert how strongly the art world has elevated First Nations and contemporary Indigenous art.

"There was a point in time where that custodianship of the story was about replicating and keeping it alive, but now we're seeing innovation," Albert says.

An artist-led approach

As much as Albert has encouraged the featured artists to push themselves and their artistic boundaries, often he found the featured artists were leading the charge themselves.

"It seems like a silly thing to say, but it should be the direction and trajectory of this decolonising, Indigenising space," Albert says.

"Setting parameters was really interesting because I know artists will always have the right answer but I've been surprised every step of the way."

Albert knew from the start he wanted to include the work of Grace Kemarre Robinya from Tangentyere Art Centre, because he is "in love with the simplistic nature of all that Gracie paints".

Robinya is the oldest artist featured in After the Rain, and the one whose work has the strongest visual connection to the cultural, environmental, social and political themes Albert wanted to explore and share.

In Robinya's 11-panel Kwatjala nhama timela (Raining time), the artist paints the rain: "We love rain because if it don't come for a long, long time it isn't good," she says. (Supplied: NGA)

"When I look at [her] work, I'm compelled to think both holistically and metaphysically about what sits within a raindrop," he says.

"But if we go back to these conversations about pushing boundaries, about doing this seminal practice, I knew from my love with Gracie and my time and relationship I've had with her, I couldn't give her a four- or five-metre canvas to paint because that was never going to happen," Albert explains.

Their solution was to provide Robinya with a series of canvases that she could "attack from every angle".

Robinya painted 11 before Albert got the call to say she was finished.

"And so by piecing all these canvases together, we get this incredible, monumental work from a very senior artist that epitomises to me the idea of what After the Rain means about being on Country and understanding Country," Albert says.

Sprouting new beginnings

Despite the excitement of After the Rain there's one element of the National Indigenous Art Triennial that has been a longstanding point of contention — the exhibition has never been every three years until now.

Warraba Weatherall, featured in the triennial, works to etch mortuary tables with patterns mirroring those in trees. (Supplied: NGA)

After the Rain follows on from Culture Warriors in 2007, unDISCLOSED in 2012, Defying Empire in 2017 and Ceremony in 2022.

"That's something we [Blak arts professionals] are concerned about and we talk about as mob, like: 'What is this thing? What is the commitment that the National Gallery has to Indigenous art?'" Albert says.

He hopes that as the first artist-led triennial, After the Rain has set parameters for the triennial's future and in doing so has also "set the tone for our own sovereignty, our own autonomy".

NATSIAA winners announced Gaypalani Waṉambi, Bulanjdjan Lucy Yarawanga, Owen Yalandja and Jahkarli Felicitas Romanis are among the winners at the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art Awards.

Looking to his own art practice, Albert says his experience as After the Rain's artistic director has solidified his desire to be given the opportunity to be heard when working with institutions and blockbuster art shows.

"[I want] for someone to take what I want to do, my idea under my autonomy and make it the best possible for me," he says.

"That's what I did for the artists in After the Rain. And that's I think all we want as artists, for someone to lift us, to put the time, energy, and resources into making our dreams come true."

The 5th National Indigenous Art Triennial: After the Rain is at National Gallery of Australia until April 26.

title: Asbestos found in new ECU city campus, but won't be removed before it opens
text:
Asbestos has been discovered in fire doors at Perth's first inner-city university, and authorities say it will not be replaced before the brand new campus welcomes its first students early in the new year.

Edith Cowan University's flagship $853 million city campus has been jointly funded by the university and state and federal governments, and is due to open for students in semester one next year.

Government minister Jackie Jarvis revealed in parliament on Thursday the building had received an exemption from work health and safety regulations to allow it to open with "asbestos-containing material" inside.

ECU's inner-city campus in Perth is due to open its doors early next year. (Supplied: Edith Cowan University)

She said the material had been found in 14 fire doors, and the exemption had been granted "to facilitate safe completion of the doors to meet fire engineering requirements and enable completion of the construction work and scheduled occupancy".

"Door replacement was not practicable in the medium-term," she said.

"The exemption specifies a range of conditions, which include the use of class A asbestos removalists, supervision by a licensed asbestos assessor, air monitoring and compliance with specified procedures."

No asbestos exposure risk

It is understood the asbestos is within a metal frame in the custom fire doors, meaning there is low risk of exposure for staff and students.

Asbestos is prohibited in Australia because it is highly carcinogenic. Inhalation of its fibres is associated with an increased risk of respiratory diseases like asbestosis, mesothelioma and lung cancers.

ECU declined to comment, deferring to builder Multiplex, which said it became aware of the risk of asbestos in the doors in September and started testing fire doors at the city campus.

Once the 14 doors were identified, the company said, it immediately told WorkSafe and workers.

Edith Cowan University has been exempted from health and safety regulations to enable it to open in February. (ABC News: Jack Stevenson)

"WorkSafe granted an exemption for minor works on the affected fire-rated doors to enable building completion," a company spokesperson said.

"Work to remove and replace the doors will occur in a timeframe that has been agreed with WorkSafe and ECU."

Industrial Relations Minister Simone McGurk told the ABC the asbestos appeared to have been imported from overseas by a manufacturer in Queensland.

"The identification and action to prevent this importation is ongoing and is being undertaken by federal authorities including Australian Border Force," she said.

Doors to be replaced

Ms McGurk said the Department of Local Government, Industry Regulation and Safety was satisfied Multiplex was "managing the risks appropriately".

"The doors will be removed and replaced during semester breaks," she said.

It comes after asbestos was recently discovered in brake pads at a number of Australian wind farms and in coloured sand.

Asked earlier in the week whether any of those brake pads were in use in Western Australia, Ms McGurk told parliament regulating the material remained a challenge.

Asbestos was recently discovered in brake pads used in wind turbines. (ABC Capricornia: Katrina Beavan)

"Products are imported from China, for instance, but other countries may not have guidelines that are as stringent as the ones we have in Western Australia," she said.

"We need to work with our federal authorities to ensure we understand that the materials we bring in from overseas have undergone the same sorts of checks we would expect any domestically manufactured or sourced products to go through."

title: Roger Cook wants to use parliament to avoid FOMO. Not everyone is on board
text:
While most West Australians are busy thinking of Christmas presents and summer holidays, many of the state's politicians are preoccupied with something else.

Whether or not to help Premier Roger Cook with his self-admitted fear of missing out.

He's not worried about missing out on concert tickets though.

The premier has "big, shiny, job-creating projects" on his mind — and he's anxious other places will snap them up.

Job creation is on the premier's mind in his push to spruik the new legislation. (ABC News: Andrew O'Connor)

Roger Cook wants the parliament to give him — and whoever else succeeds him — wide-reaching powers to change the rules on approvals for hand-picked projects.

It has prompted concern from the opposition, environmentalists and even lawyers about potential consequences.

What's changing?

The legislation would give extra powers to the state development minister (currently Mr Cook) and the coordinator general (a government-appointed bureaucrat) in relation to "priority projects".

That could be almost anything considered to be of "strategic or economic significance" by both the state development minister and the premier.

Oakajee, north of Geraldton, is an example of where infrastructure has been built for future industrial development. (ABC Midwest & Wheatbelt: Chris Lewis)

"This check and balance on power is actually just a conversation inside Premier Cook's head, because he is the minister and premier," Greens MLC Sophie McNeill told parliament on Thursday.

State development areas can also be established to make it easier for the government to provide infrastructure like power and water ahead of time to attract new industry.

With a few exceptions, the minister or coordinator general will be able to change existing approvals pathways for priority projects or state development areas in four ways if the law is passed in its current form:

Modification orders allow the minister to change how laws apply to a project, but cannot remove approval requirements altogether.

Joint decision notices escalate disagreements up the chain — if a decision isn't agreed upon between the agency and the coordinator general or the relevant minister and state development minister, the premier can have the ultimate say.
