Due regard notices force decision makers to consider specific factors they’d otherwise only consider optionally.

One big project already announced is the expansion of the Henderson shipyard south of Perth into a major defence hub. (Supplied: Australian Department of Defence)

What's the reaction been?

It won't surprise you to hear business, and especially the resources industry, are fully on board.

WA's Chamber of Commerce and Industry said it would allow the state to "capitalise on global trends" like critical minerals, defence and advanced manufacturing.

"These laws are designed to improve efficiency within government and speed up assessments without compromising on their rigour," Chamber of Minerals and Energy policy director Anita Logiudice said.

Anita Logiudice is right behind the proposed legislation. (Supplied)

"If a project fails to tick all the required boxes it will still be rejected — the proponent will just get there much faster."

What are critics saying?

In short, they say the new powers give the minister and coordinator general too much power and risk slowing down projects, rather than speeding them up.

There are also concerns that while the powers have been sold as speeding up approvals for renewable energy projects, there is nothing stopping a future government using them for any type of project.

Critics fear the changes will be used to prioritise projects far more harmful than renewable energy developments. (ABC Great Southern: Mark Bennett)

"The botched drafting of this bill is like doing surgery with a sledgehammer instead of a scalpel," Greenpeace Australia Pacific CEO David Ritter said.

"Prioritising clean energy projects through due process approvals is one thing, but this perverse shemozzle could allow polluting projects to cut corners on important, independent processes that are there to protect communities and nature."

David Ritter says the legislation is a "perverse shemozzle". (ABC News: Grace Burmas)

The Law Society of WA, which represents lawyers, also isn't supportive, warning a lack of objective criteria to choose priority projects could create a "new bottleneck" of companies seeking "special treatment with no consistent way to assess merit or priority".

"We will provide a framework of priorities so that there's absolute clarity around what are the priorities," Energy Minister Amber-Jade Sanderson explained on Thursday.

Has something like this been tried before?

It certainly has — and the Liberals' energy spokesperson Steve Thomas says none of those attempts to speed up the bureaucratic process worked.

"Do you know how I can prove this? We are sitting here today debating the government's seventh attempt to streamline approvals and put appropriate infrastructure in place," he told parliament on Tuesday.

WA's accelerated planning laws under scrutiny Planning reforms the WA government says were brought in to combat "naysayers" and "NIMBYs" are set to be put under the microscope by an upper house committee.

The most notable attempt was in 2023 when the government stripped the Environmental Protection Authority of the power to factor in carbon emissions when considering projects, saying that was already regulated under federal environmental law.

One of Labor's own MPs later broke ranks to criticise that, describing it as a "wish list that certain industry groups have been touting for years", before ultimately voting for the changes.

So why do we need these new laws?

Addressing a friendly crowd at a business breakfast last week, the premier said his FOMO took hold after a decision by mining magnate-turned-climate change campaigner Andrew Forrest.

Loading...

He'd decided to build a hydrogen electrolyser manufacturing facility in Queensland, rather than WA, in Cook's retelling, because the site already had infrastructure in place.

"That was a signal to me that we're living in a different paradigm now when it comes to developing these strategic industrial areas," the premier said.

"They have to be ready to go, because companies will come and say, 'How quickly can we establish, how quickly can we build, how quickly can we get our product to the market?'"

Mr Cook said that meant having both development-ready areas prepared and approvals laws that gave quick answers.

Will the laws pass?

Almost certainly, it's just a matter of when.

The Greens tried unsuccessfully to send the bill to a committee for closer consideration, but that failed without the opposition's support.

"We understand this is important, we understand the significance of it and we understand that the sector has been broadly in support of it," opposition leader Basil Zempilas said on Tuesday.

WA Liberal leader Basil Zempilas says his party understands the bill is important. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

The opposition's support is conditional on Labor voting for a handful of amendments put forward by Dr Thomas, including requiring the government to tell parliament when it uses certain powers.

The Greens have described that as a "dirty deal".

No matter what you call it though, it will mean the legislation should pass the upper house before its last sitting day for the year on Thursday.

It will then have to go back down to the lower house — meaning some MPs will have their Christmas holidays cut slightly short to make it back for a special sitting on December 16.

title: Victorian hobby club opens 'Australia's biggest' miniature railway
text:
A hobby club in central Victoria has spent a decade building what they claim is "Australia's biggest" miniature railway.

It was a 2012 visit to the world's pinnacle of miniature railway, Train Mountain in Portland, Oregon, that set the wheels in motion.

Andrew Mierisch, a lifelong enthusiast, and a group of friends had shipped over three engines they'd built, wanting to take them on a run on the American track.

After the six-hour miniature train ride Andrew had made up his mind — "Australia needs one of these".

Andrew Mierisch says the miniature railway station is modelled on Maryborough's train station. (ABC News: Anna McGuinness)

Thirteen years later and the Victorian Miniature Railway is officially opening to the public this weekend.

The 2.7-kilometre track is nestled on the slopes of a former paddock in Harcourt, central Victoria.

While just a fraction of Train Mountain's 523 kilometres, the 26-hectare Harcourt site means there's plenty of room to grow.

Family passion

Andrew has been around miniature railways his whole life.

His father, Colin Mierisch, was involved in the Diamond Valley Railway at Eltham, on the outskirts of Melbourne, for decades.

Andrew and Colin Mierisch take in the view from the overpass. (ABC News: Anna McGuinness)

"I've always been my dad's shadow, I was that little budding apprentice beside his father," Andrew said.

He remembers pushing a matchbox around in the dirt and then getting to drive the trains himself as he got older.

Colin is a toolmaker by trade and said his passion began when his own father bought him a steam engine when he was 7 years old.

"The thing I do enjoy the most is the passengers," Colin said.

" The little kids jumping on the train with such excitement and taking them for an enjoyable ride on the train. "

Colin Mierisch on the train platform. (ABC News: Anna McGuinness)

The father and son are just a small part of the Victorian Miniature Railway club, home to more than 50 members all dedicating their passion, skill and time to the project.

So much so that Andrew estimates 95 per cent of the work has been done by the club members.

"It's such a massive feat, to fund it wouldn't be financially possible or viable. It's only a hobby and a club at the end of the day," he said.

Many are "genuine train nuts", but others are there to tinker and make things or put their green thumb towards transforming the old paddock.

And nothing about the railway is an accident.

One of the model trains ready to take passengers for a ride. (ABC News: Anna McGuinness)

From the station — modelled on the 130-year-old train station at Maryborough, 50 kilometres west of Harcourt — to the tracks, diesel and steam engine trains.

"We are fanatical modellers," Andrew said.

"We aim for every detail — the door handle, the horns, windows, the glass, we put everything on there we possibly can."

The scale, 2.5 inches to every foot, is strictly adhered to — apart from carriage seats to allow for a comfortable ride.

Opening at last

Andrew said it's been a "really hard" decade of work after hitting unexpected granite and rock on the site and being stalled for two years by COVID.

He said the whole club is eager to let the public in and share their work, for more than one reason.

"It can get pretty boring just driving around in circles by yourself," Andrew said.

Members of the Victorian Miniature Railway during the build. (Supplied: Victorian Miniature Railway)

The railway's opening weekend, December 6 and 7, is just another milestone for the club.

"It's a bit like restoring a car — you're always going to want to make something a bit better, add, or get the next thing," Andrew said.

The tickets, at $5 a ride, are a "peppercorn rate" to cover the bills for the club, which will open to the public each Sunday going forward.

As for Harcourt, a town of about 1,000 people known for its apple cider and scenic bush backyard, Andrew said he is confident it's about to make a splash on the global miniature railway scene.

title: Frank Gehry, world-renowned architect behind Guggenheim Bilbao, dies aged 96
text:
Frank Gehry, who became a superstar of world architecture with daring creations of leaning towers and sweeping sheets of curved metal such as the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, has died at the age of 96.

The world-renowned designer of the "paper bag" building at the University of Technology Sydney died on Friday morning at his home in Santa Monica, California, after a brief respiratory illness, according to Meaghan Lloyd, the chief of staff at his architecture firm.

Gehry's most memorable and riotous creations often looked as if they had recently collapsed in an artistic manner — or were in the process of doing so. They were lauded as works of genius or reviled as self-indulgent messes.

His works were so fantastical that sometimes even he was not sure what he had wrought, as was the case with the Bilbao museum.

The Guggenheim in Bilbao, Spain, has been hailed as one of the great works of modern architecture. (Reuters: Guillermo Martinez)

In 2010, a panel of experts put together by Vanity Fair cited it as the most important work of architecture since 1980.

Eminent architect Philip Johnson called it "the greatest building of our time" and Gehry "the greatest architect we have".

However, Gehry himself said that "it took a couple of years" before he started to like it.

"I went there just before the opening and looked at it and said, 'Oh, my God, what have I done to these people?'" Gehry said.

Museums, Facebook campus among works

In March 2015, Facebook's campus in Menlo Park, California, opened a massive expansion designed by Gehry, who was given instructions not to be so bold that the facility would not fit in with its surroundings.

Gehry also opened La Fondation Louis Vuitton museum in Paris in 2014.

La Fondation Louis Vuitton in Paris was inspired by the glasshouses that previously stood on the site. (Reuters: Charles Platiau)

French billionaire Bernard Arnault, CEO of the LVMH group, paid tribute to Gehry following his passing.

"Frank Gehry — who possessed an unparalleled gift for shaping forms, pleating glass like canvas, making it dance like a silhouette — will long endure as a living source of inspiration for Louis Vuitton," he said in a statement.

Frank Gehry opens UTS building likened to 'paper bag' Architect Frank Gehry says the Dr Chau Chak Wing Building at the University of Technology Sydney was inspired by renaissance artists' fascination with folds in skin and clothing.

His other notable buildings included the Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, the Dancing House in Prague, the Experience Music Project in Seattle and the 8 Spruce residential tower in New York.

Gehry's critics accused him of disregarding function in favour of form.

His Disney concert hall was lambasted by various critics as "a pile of broken crockery", "a fortune cookie gone berserk", "deconstructionist trash" and "an emptied waste basket".

His first Australian design, the Dr Chau Chak Wing building at UTS in Sydney, was likened to a paper bag when it was opened in 2015.

Gehry tried to shrug off such criticism, telling The New Yorker in 2007, "You kind of say, 'At least they're looking!'"

But he was not always so sanguine. While in Spain in October 2014 to accept an award, Gehry was asked about criticism that his work was too showy.

He raised his middle finger and said: "In this world we are living in, 98 per cent of everything that is built and designed today is pure shit. There's no sense of design, no respect for humanity or for anything else.

"They are damn buildings and that's it."

The Disney Concert Hall was labelled "a fortune cookie gone berserk" when the design was first revealed. (Reuters: Lucy Nicholson)

A lifelong love of design

Born Ephraim Owen Goldberg in 1929 in Toronto, Canada, Gehry began designing buildings and miniature cities out of scraps of wood as a child.

"That's what I remembered, years later, when I was struggling to find out what I wanted to do in life," he told The New Yorker in 1977.

" It made me think about architecture. It also gave me the idea that an adult could play. "

After graduating from the University of Southern California, Gehry went through a restless period.

He worked at a couple of Los Angeles architecture firms, began studies at the Harvard Graduate School of Design but quit without a degree, served a year in the US Army and moved to Paris for a year.

By the time he returned to Los Angeles in 1962, he had changed his last name to Gehry, at his wife's suggestion, as a way to avoid antisemitism.

Frank Gehry's Santa Monica residence is a mainstay of Los Angeles architecture tours. (Supplied: Architectural Resources Group)

His breakthrough project was in 1978, when he rebuilt his own Santa Monica home — taking a pink traditional Dutch colonial house and turning it into something fantastical with common materials such as chain-link fencing, corrugated aluminium and unfinished plywood.

By the mid-1980s, he was attracting international attention with buildings sheathed in stainless steel or aluminium that seemed to bend and sway, subverting the conventions of architecture.

In 1989, he won the Pritzker Prize, his profession's most prestigious award.

But his masterpiece came when he was charged with designing the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, completed in 1997 using computer software that enabled him to build in increasingly eccentric shapes.

Gehry, who was married twice and had four children, also designed furniture, jewellery, watches, a bottle for a vodka distiller and a hat for singer Lady Gaga that looked like a tall, crumpled mass of silver fabric.

Reuters/ABC

title: Piastri struggles as Norris leads Abu Dhabi F1 practice
text:
Oscar Piastri has suffered a tough, truncated opening day in practice at the title-deciding Abu Dhabi Grand Prix, as teammate and championship leader Lando Norris laid down a significant early marker by going fastest in both sessions.

The Australian driver was left frustrated at the Yas Marina circuit on Friday, forced to take a mandatory break in morning practice before taking time to find his feet in the under-lights second session when he finished 11th quickest, 0.68 seconds slower than Norris's best lap of 1:23.083.

How to follow Oscar Piastri during the F1 title decider this weekend The Formula 1 world drivers' championship has gone down to the wire, with three drivers set to battle it out for glory at the season-finale Abu Dhabi Grand Prix.

It was the perfect boost for the Briton, who is 12 points ahead of Red Bull's Max Verstappen and 16 ahead of McLaren colleague Piastri, as the Dutch champion, second quickest on the day, still finished 0.363 slower than Norris under the floodlights.

Verstappen was also noted by stewards for impeding Norris in the first flashpoint of the weekend after the champion had been fed wrong information by his race engineer, but they decided not to investigate further.

"What's this guy doing? I almost crashed," Norris had been left exclaiming.

For Piastri, desperate for the pace he had in Qatar last weekend when only McLaren's strategy blunder stopped him sweeping every session, it felt a stop-start day as, first, he spent the morning on the team's pitwall.

While Norris led Verstappen by 0.008sec in another one-two, he gave up his seat to reserve Pato O'Ward in a session designed largely for young prospects and development drivers.

Piastri was doubtless itching to get out on track as his McLaren boss Zak Brown joked: "There's some guy that has taken my seat!"

The humble beginngs that define Oscar Piastri After finishing dead last in his first ever race, Oscar Piastri has risen from humble beginnings to the brink of Australian sporting history as he chases his first F1 world title.

Not much of a laughing matter for Piastri, though, as he started on the back foot in the second session, more representative of what they will all face on Sunday.

He locked up on his quickest lap and couldn't get near Norris's fastest, with Brown noting: "Oscar is not totally dialled in yet but he will get there."

Piastri certainly did not seem concerned, appearing his usual unflappable self as he told reporters: "Finding my feet. Clearly, some things to try and improve for tomorrow, but after just one session, not too bad.

Oscar Piastri is facing the biggest weekend of his F1 career — but he still has time for the fans. (AP: Darko Bandic)

"It's more just little details, the car feels like it's in a pretty decent place, but just didn't get the grip out of it on that first soft lap. So some small tweaks for tomorrow, of course. It didn't feel perfect out there, but nothing major."

Norris did not evidently want to get too high himself so early in the week, saying: "Obviously, from the times, things look good at the minute, but I still want a bit more from the car. I'm not completely happy, or completely confident.

"We all know it gets a lot closer going into quali. So nothing to smile about just yet."

Verstappen had more than a few grumbles about the Friday set-up of his Red Bull, complaining in the morning that "something is broken on the car".

Asked what the main issues were by his race engineer Gianpiero Lambiase, he replied: "It is everywhere now."

Mercedes' George Russell, who could play a key role yet in Sunday's race, was third quickest in second practice.

Brown, meanwhile, revealed McLaren might yet employ team orders in the race, after speculation all week that Piastri could be asked to move over for Norris, sacrificing his own slight championship chance if it appeared Verstappen could be heading for overall victory.

Piastri quiet on key F1 title question Oscar Piastri dodges the question of whether he might help Lando Norris lift the world F1 title in Abu Dhabi, saying McLaren has not discussed the issue.

Brown admitted: "If, as the race develops, it becomes clear one of our drivers has a significantly better chance than the other, then we're a team that wants to win the drivers' championship and we will race accordingly, to do whatever we can to get that driver in front to try and win the race."

He did not say what sort of chance would qualify as "significantly better," but indicated team orders would only come into play if "it becomes clear that both (Norris and Piastri) can't" win.

Asked if he believed Piastri would agree to any order to help out Norris, Brown said: "Yes. Our drivers have always complied with team wishes, just as we comply with their wishes.

"I've got no doubt either of our drivers will continue to race as they've done brilliantly, in the best interest of the team."

AAP

title: Paralympian returns to sport after 25 years to help next generation of athletes
text:
When Paralympian Mellissa Dunn rolls onto a Darwin basketball court today, she is surrounded by the kind of energy and support she once only dreamed of.

Twenty-five years ago, high-performance wheelchair basketball in the Northern Territory looked like just a handful of determined athletes, a borrowed gym and no coaches in sight.

Most mornings Dunn practised before the gates of the local school she trained at opened, the sound of her wheelchair tyres echoing through empty gym halls as the sun came up.

Despite those barriers, Dunn went on to reach the Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games — winning a silver medal while four months pregnant.

"That was definitely the highlight," she says, smiling.

Mellissa Dunn won a silver medal in wheelchair basketball at the Sydney 2000 Paralympic Games. (Supplied: Mellissa Dunn)

" After that, my life changed dramatically. "

With limited means to both support her new family and chase her sporting dreams, Mellissa retired in her mid-20s.

Now, after 25 years, Dunn is back on court.

As both a player in the National Wheelchair Basketball League and a mentor back home in Darwin, she is helping to shape the next generation of territory athletes.

A life-changing accident that led to a new beginning

At the age of 17, Dunn's life was turned upside down.

"In 1994 I was completing Year 12 and was involved in a car accident involving a drunk driver," she says.

" I broke my back and injured my neck and became an incomplete paraplegic. "

During rehabilitation in Adelaide, a physiotherapist introduced Dunn to wheelchair basketball.

She watched Australian athletes training — strong, confident and laughing together — and asked if she could join in.

That moment changed everything.

Mellissa Dunn says playing wheelchair basketball and pursuing a Paralympic career was life-changing. (ABC News: Marcus Kennedy)

But back home in Darwin, Paralympic success seemed out of reach.

There were no coaches, no specialist facilities and few others to train with — just determination and a lot of improvisation.

Equipment was scarce and travel costs were crushing.

"If we wanted to get exposure to the game, we'd spend our weekends at the petrol station, begging people to buy a raffle ticket to support our travels down south," she says.

" You had to be more motivated and determined, because you were pretty much on your own. "

From isolation to a training community

For years para-athletes in the NT trained in isolation. But recently, that has begun to change.

The Para Futures Pathways Program, led by Jodie Zanini through the NT Sports Academy, has built the structure for athletes that Dunn once lacked throughout the Northern Territory.

It provides access to qualified coaches, strength and conditioning facilities, gym support, regular competition and athlete development workshops.

The Para Futures Pathways Program is giving more NT para-athletes access to the training and facilities they need to be successful. (ABC News: Marcus Kennedy)

Launched in 2022, the program now supports more than 20 athletes aged 13 to 35.

It also applies to those living outside of Darwin, where barriers to access like distance and cost make the challenges even greater.

Zanini says while it can be challenging to reach athletes across such a vast region, the goal is inclusion for all Territorians, from Darwin to remote Arnhem Land.

"The whole point of this system uplift is to bring people along for the ride quicker," Zanini says.

Jodie Zanini says the aim of the program is to give para-athletes the support they need to achieve their goals more quickly. (ABC News: Marcus Kennedy)

"We want more athlete representation by the 2032 Brisbane Paralympics, and for people with disabilities to have real opportunities here at home."

The difference the program has made, Dunn says, is "life-changing".

And where NT para-athletes once trained mostly on their own, Zanini says today the program allows up-and-coming athletes to train alongside their peers, providing a sense of community.

"What brought me back to wheelchair basketball was the fabulous community we have," Dunn says.

"Everyone is so supportive of each other."

The pathways program gives para-athletes access to gym support. (ABC News: Marcus Kennedy)

That sense of belonging is what Zanini wants every athlete to experience.

"Anyone with a disability can come and try sport," she says.

"Not everyone feels comfortable just rocking up to a club.

" We make sure there's a pathway for them after they try it. "

"The whole point is to bring people along for the ride quicker and create a legacy that lasts beyond 2032."

17yo Arnhem Land para athlete set to compete in world championships Arnhem Land teenager Briseis Brittain is set to represent Australia at the World Para Athletics Championships in New Delhi, competing in the 200m and 400m races.

Dunn says she can see the difference.

"Back then, we had to organise everything ourselves: travel, accommodation, airfares," she says.

"These days there's support, so athletes can focus on training and improving.

"At this stage in my life, I'm happy to support other athletes coming through."

NT growing pathways to 2032

Natalie Charlton from Paralympics Australia says the NT's rapid progress in para-athlete development has caught national attention.

"It's not a matter of the NT catching up to the rest of the nation. The NT is doing incredible things and developing pathways," she says.

Natalie Charlton says the NT is no longer catching up to the rest of the country when it comes to opportunities on offer to para-athletes. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

Charlton says she hopes the territory's homegrown athletes will feature strongly in the Brisbane 2032 Paralympic Games.

"I'd love to see athletes representing at the 2032 Games, who've been able to develop as athletes at home in the Northern Territory," she says.

Dunn comes full-circle

Dunn isn't looking to don the green and gold again and play for Australia. Instead, she has set her sights on inspiring the next generation.

"I'd like to see younger athletes have the same incredible opportunities that I got to experience," she says.

"I hope that one day I can inspire future athletes in the same way previous athletes have inspired me.

" Behind every success is a great community. "

title: Death prompts major hospital protocol overhaul as inquest scrutinises 'chaotic day'
text:
A Queensland hospital has increased staffing and revamped its radiology protocols following the death of an 87-year-old farmer after routine surgery, an inquest has heard.

Ten Sunshine Coast University Hospital (SCUH) staff were cross examined at a coronial inquest this week in order for Deputy State Coroner Stephanie Gallagher to determine the circumstances of Terry Airey's death on June 11, 2022.

The beloved father and grandfather, who lived in Gympie for more than 50 years, leaves behind his wife Josie and six children from two marriages.

The four-day inquest heard his death was a result of organ failure after surgery performed by an unsupervised training doctor.

Outside the Maroochydore Magistrates Court where the inquest was held, family members told the ABC they wanted to understand the "human error" at play in his death to prevent similar, preventable deaths from befalling another family.

'Chaotic day' of surgery

Mr Airey presented to SCUH for a scheduled surgery, in pain with a cyst that was described in court as "gigantic", "unusual", and "uncommon" on Wednesday June 8, 2022.

He was admitted to the hospital's interventional radiology suite.

Bianca Stringer, the barrister representing Sunshine Coast Hospital and Health Service, said it was a "chaotic day".

Dr Roger Wilson — who was undergoing his fellowship at SCUH under the supervision of Dr Johnathon Langton and Dr Paul Leschke — drained Mr Airey's kidney cyst of about 2 litres of fluid.

Dr Wilson told the court he was taught to refill the cyst with half the amount that was drained.

However, there was only 320ml of the medical grade ethanol available.

Dr Langton told the court his rule of thumb was to never exceed 100ml of ethanol.

Dr Leschke said he was aware of both guidelines.

The court heard Mr Airey was exposed to toxic levels of alcoholic betadine, 30 per cent, and medical grade ethanol at 96 or 98 per cent, but treated by staff as 100 per cent.

Coroner Gallagher established it was an inappropriate amount of ethanol to instil but did not contribute to the death.

Cyst not drained a third time

After the procedure, while in recovery, a senior nurse drained and refilled Mr Airey's cyst twice with 1 litre of alcoholic betadine, rotating him in between.

The court heard the nurses expected Dr Wilson to perform the final drainage.

Dr Wilson said he believed the nurses had performed the final drainage, though he aspirated about 20ml of residual fluid.

No staff used the ultrasound in the recovery room to check if Mr Airey's cyst had been drained, the court heard.

The inquest will determine if adequate procedures are now in place to prevent similar deaths. (ABC News: Jake Grant)

Expert witness Dr John Richards, the medical director of imaging at Gold Coast University Hospital, told the court rotating an older patient could have kinked the catheter and contributed to his death.

The inquest heard on the evening of the surgery, Mr Airey returned to Gympie, about 100 kilometres away, with 1 litre of alcoholic betadine still in his cyst and the drain removed.

Later that night, Mr Airey presented to the Gympie Hospital and was transferred back to SCUH where his cyst was drained the following day.

He died three days later on June 11.

Hospital protocol overhauled following death

The inquest heard since Mr Airey's death SCUH had increased staffing and implemented procedural changes, with senior doctors to be the primary operators and to not allow nurses to perform drainage and exchanges.

There were also updates to the tracking of fluids in the patient, with a paper fluid chart staying with every patient in recovery and ultrasounds being undertaken after every procedure.

Staff must breathalyse each sclerotherapy procedure patient before the procedure and not continue if they do not blow zero.

They must also breathalyse each sclerotherapy procedure patient after the procedure and the patient must blow zero or below 0.05 with two readings showing a downward trajectory.

The hospital also implemented that one nurse stay with the patient in recovery until they are discharged. Mr Airey was passed on to multiple nurses.

Surgeries were also scheduled for earlier in the day, as Mr Airey's surgery was pushed back to after 2pm.

Doctors are not too instil more than 100ml of ethanol, complex surgeries are double scrubbed, and rosters are distributed eight weeks in advance with staff pre-assigned duties.

Hospital staff have also been given written sclerotherapy procedure protocols and guidelines.

Speaking to media outside court the Airey family said it was satisfied with the changes.

Coroner Gallagher also commended SCUH for implementing the changes.

She said she would only take submissions regarding instilling and not draining the last litre of alcoholic betadine as this had ultimately caused Mr Airey's death.

Coroner Gallagher's findings are expected in six to eight months.

title: The simple approach Cam Smith is adopting as he chases Australian Open win
text:
When Cameron Smith was asked what it would take for him to win the Australian Open ahead of the final two rounds, his answer was blunt.

"Good golf," the 2022 British Open champion told reporters following his second round at Royal Melbourne on Friday.

To say the least, Smith's reply did not beat around the bush.

But it did reflect the simple approach he adopted as he moved into contention for the Stonehaven Cup with a bogey-free 6-under-par 65 in the second round.

McIlroy nervously avoids Australian Open cut Five-time major champion Rory McIlroy survives to fight another day at the Australian Open.

Smith sank six birdies to share fourth place on 7-under with fellow Australian major winner Adam Scott and Mexican Carlos Ortiz.

It will be more of the same for Smith on 'moving day', the colloquial title given to the third round, as he looks to chase down co-leaders Rasmus Neergaard-Petersen and Daniel Rodrigues, who are 9-under for the tournament.

"I don't think I need to do anything different," Smith said.

"That (second round) was just really solid, really committed to shapes, and shots and flights. It was just nice to do that. I gained a lot of confidence out of that."

Despite describing himself as a "pretty gritty player", Smith cut a casual figure as he strode the fairways in his second round, playing alongside rising Australian star Elvis Smylie and Englishman Danny Willett.

The laid-back Queenslander seemed to thrive on the fact much of the spectator interest surrounded the star-studded trio of Rory McIlroy, Min Woo Lee and Scott, who were playing ahead of his group.

Cameron Smith (right) played with Danny Willett during the second round on Friday. (Getty Images: Josh Chadwick)

That is not to say the galleries following Smith, Smylie and Willett were lacking in numbers, as there was enough fan support to create a vibrant atmosphere.

"There wasn't yelling and screaming out there, thank God," Smith said.

"There was a lot of people. But it was good fun out there."

Smith's form line ahead of the Australian Open might have left tournament organisers anxious about whether one of their drawcards would be playing this weekend.

After a promising start to the Australian PGA Championship in Brisbane last week, Smith capitulated in his second round to miss the cut at 2-over.

The 32-year-old comfortably avoided the same fate in Melbourne but stressed he did not travel to the Victorian capital just to make up the numbers.

"I'm not here to make the cut," Smith said.

"I'm here to win the Stonehaven Cup and I've put myself in a good spot to do that, so I'm really happy with that."

Smith, Scott and Ortiz will tee off in the second-last group of the third round at 11.39am AEDT.

title: When will construction begin on the Hobart stadium?
text:
After three and a half years, the question of whether Tasmania is getting a new stadium — and with it an AFL team — has been answered.

But now that the parliamentary fight is over, how does the stadium actually get built? And when exactly will the Macquarie Point precinct transform from an industrial wasteland to an elite sporting hub?

Let's take a look.

The official timeline has the Devils starting to play at the new stadium in 2029. (Supplied: MPDC)

First things first — will the stadium be ready for 2029?

Macquarie Point Development Corporation chief executive Anne Beach is in charge of transforming the site, best known at the moment for hosting bits of the Dark Mofo winter festival and as the home of a sewage plant.

She says it's too early to commit to when AFL games could first be hosted on the new ground.

"We'll be able to lock down and communicate clearly with the community the timelines and the key milestones along that delivery pathway and what they can expect to see when once we appoint the major construction contractor," Ms Beach said.

Tasmania Devils CEO Brendon Gale (centre). (ABC News: Mackenzie Heard)

But Tasmania Devils chief executive Brendon Gale says he's not holding his breath that the stadium will be ready for Round 1 in 2029, despite it being in the contract between the AFL and the state government.

"It's probably an assumption internally that we'll be playing games in Hobart and Launceston at Bellerive and York Park for two years," he said.

With the Devils set to enter the AFL in 2028, that means he's preparing for it to be ready in 2030.

Who will build it?

The stadium will be built in the Macquarie Point precinct. (ABC News: Kate Nickels)

A yet-to-be-appointed major contractor.

The process to find a builder, who will also help to finalise the stadium's design, won't be quick.

Ms Beach says she hopes an expression of interest process to find that contractor will open in January, with a tender process to follow.

The time frame for the actual appointment of that contractor is the final quarter of 2026, so October to December next year.

When will construction actually begin?

There's going to be a fair bit happening on the site next year (more on that below), but Ms Beach says building a stadium won't actually start for about 18 months.

That's because the corporation first needs to appoint a contractor, and get building and plumbing approval from the Hobart City Council.

"So we would expect to hopefully have everything in place to start around May 2027," she said.

A render of the internal concourse around the edge of the seating bowl at the Macquarie Point stadium. (Supplied: MPDC)

Can the stadium really be delivered on budget?

That's the question that will come up endlessly over the next few years.

As part of deals to get the stadium through parliament, the state government committed to limiting the amount paid by Tasmanian taxpayers at $875 million.

That means it has only two options if the project budget blows out again: make decisions to "value manage" the project and reduce its cost, or get extra funding from the federal government, Cricket Australia, the AFL or private investors.

What would it be like to visit the proposed Hobart stadium? Setting all the politics aside — just for a moment — what would it actually be like to visit the building at the heart of Tasmania's fiery stadium debate?

Ms Beach says MPDC has already made a series of decisions to value manage the project.

"There are efficiencies in the way that the foundations are done, the way we support different structures," she said.

"One, for example, is the rakers, which is the steel that supports the concrete seating bowl. By moving those to a double raker rather than a single gave us some efficiencies and some savings in steel."

She says those decisions will be made throughout the process, making sure that cost is managed without compromising the quality of the stadium.

Macquarie Point Development Corporation boss Anne Beach and Tasmanian Treasurer Eric Abetz at the construction site. (ABC News: Kate Nickels)

Treasurer Eric Abetz says he's confident the project can be delivered for the current price tag, continually stressing that the government has received what's called a "P90" — which is a cost estimate made by a quantity surveyor with 90 per cent certainty.

But as economist Saul Eslake points out, construction costs continue to rise.

He says it's likely that the $1.13 billion estimate will increase by the time the stadium is delivered.

How the government responds if and when that happens will be crucial.

Does any work happen between now and the contractor appointment?

Yes. Two big tenders have just gone out.

The first is to excavate contaminated soil (it is a former industrial site after all) and to level the land.

'Fair assumption': Devils boss warns of stadium debut delay The Tasmania Devils CEO says the club will likely play in the AFL from existing venues for a year longer than expected.

Ms Beach says there's still about 130,000 cubic metres, or 220,000 tonnes of contaminated land on the site.

The other tender is to dismantle the heritage-listed Goods Shed, which will eventually be relocated at the concourse level on the northern end of the site.

Ms Beach says the pieces of shed will be stored for a couple of years, until an underground half-ring road and a few other facilities are built below it.

The company that wins the tender will also be in charge of working out exactly how the shed will actually be dismantled, and then put back together.

One of the first steps will be to dismantle the heritage-listed Goods Shed. (Supplied: Nearmap)

What happens to the Red Shed?

That shed is the home of Hobart Brewing Co.

The plan is for that to be removed soon after the company's lease ends in June, at roughly the same time as the Goods Shed is packed up.

Is there any work to test the roof?

Cricket Australia is pretty confident that the stadium will be able to host domestic and international cricket matches, despite some initial concerns.

But Ms Beach says a test rig to examine what shadows will be cast by the proposed roof, how much light it lets in, and what it means for grass growth, will be installed on the site in February next year to make sure that the roof design delivers before the tender process begins.

title: The 100 days, 21 countries and one fractured skull behind one Pom's wild Ashes tour
text:
There are intrepid travellers, then there's Manchester's Tommy Lamb.

The 18-year-old cricket fanatic has already travelled through 21 countries in an odyssey that's taken more than 100 days in an effort to make it to Adelaide Oval for the third Ashes Test.

The challenge: make the entire trip overland or by sea. No planes allowed.

The plan is to join his parents, who are both members of the Barmy Army supporting the England cricket team on the Ashes tour.

He told Saturday Extra's Nick Bryant why he was inspired to take on such an epic trek.

Australia delights in English woe Australia took control of the second Ashes Test at the Gabba on a day that carried plenty of the hallmarks of failed English tours of yesteryear.

"It'd be a great way to get myself off the beaten path and force myself to see different parts of the world that otherwise I wouldn't go to," Lamb said.

"That's — that's the sort of travel I want to do."

His journey has taken him from England through Western Europe, into the Balkans, then south through Türkiye into Iran, Pakistan and China and on to south-east Asia.

With his trusty cricket bat in his backpack, Lamb has found a way to get a game of some sort happening in every country he's visited.

"Every time I spend the night in a place, a new place, I try and play some cricket there," Lamb said.

"You get all these people giving you weird looks: 'What on earth are you asking? What on earth are you doing?'

"But eventually you'll find a few people that are really up for it, and you end up playing a 30-minute game with a border guard on the lake in northern Albania and it's just a memory for a lifetime."

His journey was inspired by his father telling Tommy a story of one completed by Lonely Planet founders Tony and Maureen Wheeler in the early 1970s.

"I always wanted to take a year out after school [and] I've always been interested in travel. I love my cricket obviously, as well," Lamb said.

"My dad, about two years ago, was just telling a story of two people that did this same trip in the 1970s and when I heard him talking about that, I thought that sounded great.

"I knew I wanted to go to the Ashes during my year off, I knew it would collide, and I thought, well, if I could get to the Ashes without a plane, it'd be a great way to make content online."

Lamb has been publishing a daily log of his journey on his Instagram account. His video diaries have documented his travels — warts, cuts, breaks, bruises and all — including a serious motorcycle accident in Vietnam.

Loading Instagram content

"I've never driven a motorbike before, so it was just the stupidest thing you could possibly do as an 18-year-old Brit travelling in south-east Asia," Lamb said.

"So, I fractured my skull, broke my nose, had quite a few bad scratches here and there, but it wasn't the end of the world.

"Spent a few days in hospital, thankfully, was very well taken care of and then a few days in a hotel.

"I just felt worse telling my mum — that was probably the most nerve-racking part of the whole thing, rather than the accident itself."

He's experienced unexpected delights like discovering the beauty of Iran.

"Absolutely loved it, it was one of my favourite places that I've been to," Lamb said.

"I mean that there's definitely a bias here that I think when I was in Iran, every day you wake up and as a Westerner, as a Brit, you're sort of thinking, 'oh my God, I'm in Iran' and you can't quite believe it.

"It wasn't what I expected to find — it was a beautiful place with beautiful people and you gotta separate the government from the rest of it."

That was in stark contrast to his experience in the Pakistan province of Balochistan, where terrorist attacks and bombings have killed hundreds this year alone.

The Australian government's Smartraveller website recommends against travelling to the province because of the poor security situation and high risks of kidnapping.

Lamb found himself shuffled from police car to police van and spent two nights sleeping in cells.

Loading Instagram content

"I'm travelling for 12 hours in a day, that'll probably be about 20 different military escorts because every time you move district, you get into a new car," Lamb said.

"So, on the first day, I only got about halfway into Balochistan and I was in the middle of absolutely nowhere, dropped off in this town.

"It was about midnight, and they basically said to me, 'there's no hotels here. You're gonna have to stay in the prison cell.'

"I have a few Pakistani friends back home and when I told them I was going into Balochistan, they couldn't quite believe it themselves.

"My logic always goes that, you know, if the locals can survive it for their whole lives, I'm sure I can survive it for a couple of days."

His next stop was south-east Asia, where he got stuck in floods in Thailand before losing his luggage and passport after leaving them in a car. Somehow, he regained them within a day.

Loading Instagram content

If you think Lamb sounds like a somewhat naive and lucky young man, you're probably right, but he displays maturity beyond his years.

He is also exceptionally open to the world and all the experiences that have come his way.

"My older brother was a big fan of calling me a naive 18-year-old who doesn't know about the real world," Lamb said.

"But I always had this belief that … 99 per cent of the people you meet are all nice, no matter where you are in the world.

"And that's exactly what I've experienced: No matter which part of the world I'm in, I meet so many nice people that are willing to help me no matter what situation I'm in."

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

His latest "situation" is being stuck in Singapore and desperately trying to get a lift of some sort on a boat to take him further south to Indonesia.

"I've emailed every single cargo ship company I can think of, I've gone to multiple cargo ship HQs, I've gone to marinas, I've asked everyone for boats heading towards Australia," Lamb said.

He at least found time to watch Joe Root score his maiden test century in Australia from the bar of the Singapore Cricket Club.

The plan is to meet his Barmy Army parents for the third Test in Adelaide, and if he can't make that, the backstop is Boxing Day in Melbourne.

And no matter what, he won't be catching a plane.

title: Deaf residents in aged care left without basic support services
text:
Every day June Beutel sits alone, unable to connect with those around her.

The 87-year-old woman was born deaf and has spent the past two years living in a nursing home in Brisbane without Auslan support after she was diagnosed with dementia.

"She is sitting in a chair by herself, and when I come in to see her, she is signing to herself, interacting with nobody," her niece Brita Murphy said.

"[She is] profoundly deaf, she can't lip-read at all, she also has a vision impairment as well. And then having dementia as well on top of all of that … her needs are very complex."

June Beutel signs in Auslan with her niece Brita Murphy. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

Ms Murphy has spent the past two years advocating for Auslan services — the Australian Deaf community's language, for her aunt in aged care.

The process has highlighted gaps in care available for Deaf seniors in Australia.

"I feel disheartened that in 2025 it is an issue that a deaf person in an aged care facility cannot have access to Auslan," Ms Murphy said.

Chief executive of the national peak body Deaf Connect, Brett Casey, told the ABC Ms Beutel's story reflects "what many families experience when trying to secure culturally appropriate care for Deaf seniors".

"Most mainstream nursing homes do not have access to an Auslan-proficient workforce, despite that responsibility sitting with the facility," he said.

"There is a nationwide shortage of Auslan-fluent support workers and the pathway to train existing staff to an appropriate level takes time."

June Beutel's family visit her each week, including her great nieces. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

A spokesperson for the Department of Health, Disability and Ageing said while it funds Deaf Connect, who is the provider for the National Sign Laguage Program (NSLP), the NSLP "does not provide funding for aged care workers like social support or personal care workers".

These service gaps mean the only time Ms Beutel can communicate is when her family visits.

"I'll sit with her and then she'll just burst into tears," said Ms Murphy.

"She'll say 'I'm on my own, it's just me' … she is so confused."

Brita Murphy has spent the past two years advocating for Auslan support for her aunt in aged care. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

No funding available

Between full-time work, caring for her four children, and looking after her father who is also deaf, Ms Murphy has been exploring avenues for Auslan support.

She has contacted the national peak bodies Deaf Connect and Deaf Australia, the Commonwealth Volunteer Visitors Scheme, her local MP, and had a number of meetings with the Ozcare nursing home where her aunt lives.

"No matter where I go … nothing is done, no one can tell me why there is no funding or any program that can bridge that communication gap," she said.

Auslan is not included as an option in the language list when applying for My Aged Care, which Mr Casey has said means Deaf seniors face access barriers "from the first step".

Deaf man rationing Auslan interpreting after 'gutting' NDIS cut Disability advocates say cuts to Deaf participants' NDIS funding is a "systemic" problem that reflects a belief that Deafness can be "fixed".

He said Deaf Connect could provide Auslan-fluent support workers "to supplement care for some residents", but it was "only possible when the service is identified and funded by the nursing home".

In June, Ms Murphy lodged a formal complaint with the Aged Care Quality and Safety Commission, who launched an investigation into Auslan accessible services.

During the investigation, Ozcare confirmed it would provide Ms Beutel with a support worker two hours a fortnight, which only lasted a few visits due to resourcing.

"At the moment we are just back to square one … and it has just been heartbreaking to see that she is so isolated," Ms Murphy said.

June Beutel and Brita Murphy's first language is Auslan. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

Ozcare's chief executive Michael Crutcher told the ABC: "Ozcare provides as much assistance as possible to residents whose needs go beyond the usual span of aged-care support measures".

But Ms Murphy worries that if her aunt needed help, or was in pain, there would be no way for staff to know.

"She just has to basically tolerate what she's feeling, there's no ease for her," she said.

A spokesperson from the Aged Care Quality and Safety Commission said the new Aged Care Act "means that people receiving care have a right to communicate in the language or method they prefer. Aged care providers should understand and follow the Statement of Rights."

'Falling through the cracks'

According to the latest census, more than 16,000 Australians use Auslan at home, but there is no exact data on how many of these people live in aged care.

Couple 'effectively unable to be involved in care decisions' before man's death Bruce Drabsch's daughter Melinda Dagger, who was travelling to hospital to be with her ailing father, was phoned by a doctor and asked to inform her mother her husband of more than six decades had died, because no Auslan interpreter was provided.

Given her age, Ms Beutel is not eligible for NDIS funding, and because she is in aged care, she cannot access services through the Aged Care Assessment Team.

Professor Piers Dawes, director of the Centre for Hearing Research at the University of Queensland, said people like Ms Beautel can fall through the cracks.

"Hearing impairment tends to be under recognised and under supported … because it's not a visible sort of problem," he said.

Professor Dawes has led a number of national projects exploring how to better identify and support the needs of people with hearing impairments in aged care settings.

Brita Murphy signs with her aunty June Beutel (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

He said the "particular cultural and communication needs of Deaf people" are often overlooked, despite it being a basic level of care.

"The most common reason for [moving into aged care] is that people have dementia, so they are not able to look after themselves," he said.

"If you can imagine all of that being compounded by not being able to communicate well with your carers or engage in social activities … you can imagine what an awful situation that would be," he said.

Professor Piers Dawes, director of the Centre for Hearing Research at the University of Queensland, says the cultural needs of Deaf elders are often overlooked. (Supplied: Piers Dawes)

Regis Aged Care Blackburn in Victoria has a dedicated wing for Deaf residents, with staff either deaf themselves, or trained in Auslan.

Professor Dawes said more facilities like this are needed.

"There is a whole rich culture associated with the Deaf community … ideally somebody might have the option of specialised services."

Deaf advocate Sherrie Beaver said this is particularly important for "Deaf people born in the 1960s", when the rubella epidemic led to a significant number of babies born deaf in Australia.

She's worried the aged care sector is not prepared for the next two decades, when many of these individuals will likely be entering care settings.

"There are so many heartbreaking stories of Deaf seniors being isolated in aged care, not having ample access to social opportunities," she said.

title: 2025 Australian Open golf LIVE: The discarded banana peel that caused a Rory McIlroy double bogey
text:
Rory McIlroy slipped up on a banana peel with a double bogey on the second hole at Royal Melbourne to struggle in the early stages of his Australian Open third round.

The world No.2 was hoping to maintain the momentum of three birdies late in his second round when he arrived on course for an early tee time on Saturday, seven shots off the pace.

Swamped by a sell-out crowd, the Northern Irishman opened with a par but missed the fairway on the par-four second hole with his ball nestled next to a grassy bush.

The lie went from bad to worse with a discarded banana skin draping the ball, with McIlroy unable to remove it for fear of the ball moving which would mean a one-stroke penalty.

He hacked it out, the ball travelling only about 10 metres, and his third shot came up short, and he was unable to get up and down, making double-bogey.

The setback came after Friday’s embarrassment on the par-five 14th when McIlroy had a rare air swing after his tee shot finished up under a ti-tree, and he then clipped a branch on the backswing.

He was then able to escape with a one-putt bogey.

Showing his class, golf’s newest grand slam winner immediately shook off Saturday’s early blow to birdie the par-four third.

AAP

title: ‘We’re realistic’: McLaren will use team orders if necessary to secure F1 title
text:
It was the perfect boost for the Briton, who’s 12 points ahead of Verstappen and 16 ahead of McLaren colleague Piastri, as the Dutch champion, second quickest on the day, still finished 0.363 slower than Norris in his Red Bull under the floodlights. Verstappen was also noted by stewards for impeding Norris in the first flashpoint of the weekend after the champion had been fed wrong information by his race engineer, but they decided not to investigate further. Lando Norris and members of the McLaren team in Abu Dhabi. Credit: Getty Images “What’s this guy doing? I almost crashed,” Norris had been left exclaiming. For Piastri, desperate for the pace he had in Qatar last weekend when only McLaren’s strategy blunder stopped him sweeping every session, it felt a stop-start day as, first, he spent the morning on the team’s pitwall.

While Norris led Verstappen by 0.008sec in another one-two, he gave up his seat to reserve Pato O’Ward in a session designed largely for young prospects and development drivers. Piastri was doubtless itching to get out on track as his McLaren boss Zak Brown joked: “There’s some guy that has taken my seat!” Not much of a laughing matter for Piastri, though, as he started on the back foot in the second session, more representative of what they’ll all face on Sunday. He locked up on his quickest lap and couldn’t get near Norris’s fastest, with Brown noting: “Oscar is not totally dialled in yet but he will get there.”

Piastri certainly didn’t seem concerned, appearing his usual unflappable self as he told reporters: “Finding my feet. Clearly, some things to try and improve for tomorrow, but after just one session, not too bad. “It’s more just little details, the car feels like it’s in a pretty decent place, but just didn’t get the grip out of it on that first soft lap. So some small tweaks for tomorrow, of course. It didn’t feel perfect out there, but nothing major.” Norris didn’t evidently want to get too high himself so early in the week, saying: “Obviously, from the times, things look good at the minute, but I still want a bit more from the car. I’m not completely happy, or completely confident. “We all know it gets a lot closer going into quali. So nothing to smile about just yet.” Loading

Verstappen had more than a few grumbles about the Friday set-up of his Red Bull, complaining in the morning that “something is broken on the car”. Asked what the main areas of issue were by his race engineer Gianpiero Lambiase, he replied: “It is everywhere now.” Mercedes’ George Russell, who could play a key role yet in Sunday’s race, was third quickest in second practice. Brown elaborated on the prospect that McLaren might yet employ team orders in the race. Brown admitted: “If, as the race develops, it becomes clear one of our drivers has a significantly better chance than the other, then we’re a team that wants to win the drivers’ championship and we will race accordingly, to do whatever we can to get that driver in front to try and win the race.”

title: More than a dozen hospitalised overnight in e-scooter crash spike
text:
Thirteen people have been hospitalised after a spate of e-scooter and e-bike crashes across Queensland overnight ahead of fresh public hearings into the vehicles’ safety and enforcement.

Paramedics were called to 11 separate incidents, from Biloela to Palm Beach, between 6pm on Friday and 4.30am on Saturday – most in the south-east and all but two involving e-scooters.

In the worst accident, a teenage boy suffered significant foot injuries on the Gold Coast after an “e-scooter and vehicle incident” about 6pm, paramedics said.

Since their introduction in Brisbane in 2018, the popularity of e-scooters and bikes has surged – along with injuries. Credit: Matt Dennien

Then in Logan, a man in his 30s suffered what were described as significant leg injuries after an e-scooter fall just after 7pm. Both were taken to hospital in a stable condition.

title: Sydney set for its hottest day in almost two years
text:
Sydney will swelter through its hottest day in almost two years as thousands of commuters are forced off the metro due to track work.

The temperature at Observatory Hill reached 31.4 degrees at 11am, with the heat forecast to rise to 39 degrees in the Sydney CBD and 41 degrees in Penrith by 3pm, marking Sydney’s hottest day since January 2024.

Steven Crameri beats the heat at Penrith Beach on Saturday morning. Credit: Sitthixay Ditthavong

A total fire ban is in place as the Rural Fire Service attempts to contain a fire in Bulahdelah that has burnt through 2685 hectares and is not yet under control.

The smoke from the fire has drifted across Sydney and the Central Coast, blanketing the city in a light haze which is expected to clear throughout the morning.

title: Frank Gehry, titan of architecture, dies aged 96
text:
“I was rebelling against everything,” Gehry said in an interview with The New York Times in 2012, explaining his antipathy toward the dominant architectural movements of the time, as exemplified by the Farnsworth House on the Illinois prairie, a stark, flat, steel-and-glass modernist pavilion by Mies van der Rohe. “I couldn’t live in a house like that,” he said. “I’d have to come home, clean up my clothes, hang them properly. I thought it was snotty and effete. It just didn’t feel like it fit into life.” The Gehry-designed Dr Chau Chak Wing Building at UTS Business School in Sydney. Credit: Fairfax Media For some, his work was more sculpture than architecture. Others saw it as emblematic of a global culture that reduced architecture to a form of branding. Gehry, whose name was recognised around the world, was sometimes derided as a “star-chitect”. But his work’s emotional ferocity could feel empowering, as if architecture had rediscovered a part of itself that had been lost after decades of dreary functionalism and postmodernist cliches. And the widespread focus on his buildings’ dazzling exteriors could distract from Gehry’s deeper goals: to create an architecture that was not just affecting but democratic in spirit and evocative of the messiness of human life.

He was born Frank Owen Goldberg on February 28, 1929, in Toronto to Irving and Sadie (Caplan) Goldberg. His father held a series of jobs, including managing a grocery store and selling pinball and slot machines. Frank and his sister, Doreen, lived with their parents in a two-family house clad in brick and tar-paper shingles (a material he would use in some of his designs). As a boy, he worked part-time in his maternal grandfather’s hardware store, stocking the shelves with tools, screws and bolts – an experience, he said, that spawned his love of everyday materials. The Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles, another Gehry masterpiece, opened in 2003. Credit: Getty Images Once a week, his maternal grandmother would come home from the market with a live carp, another formative experience, which would inspire the fish imagery that later appeared in his work. “We’d put it in the bathtub,” Gehry recalled, “and I’d play with this fish for a day until she killed it and made gefilte fish” (a traditional Ashkenazi Jewish dish). Frank’s world abruptly fell apart in the mid-1940s, when his father, a heavy drinker, had a heart attack as the two were arguing on the front lawn, a memory that Gehry said haunted him for decades. His father never fully recovered. After a doctor warned that he would not survive another Toronto winter, the family moved to Los Angeles, renting a cramped $US50-a-month apartment in a run-down neighbourhood just west of downtown.

As an architect, Gehry was a late bloomer. After a brief stint in the army, he married Anita Snyder, who helped pay his way through the University of Southern California, where he initially studied ceramics. He shifted to architecture after a teacher introduced him to Raphael Soriano, a pillar of postwar modernism in Southern California. (It was around this time, too, that he adopted Gehry as his surname, a somewhat random choice inspired, he said, by the desire to avoid antisemitism.) Gehry spent several years toiling as a mid-level designer and project manager at Gruen Associates, a firm known for its shopping malls. After he opened his own office in 1962, much of his early work was for mainstream developers. He designed a sprawling headquarters for the Rouse Co. in Columbia, Maryland, and two unremarkable department stores for Joseph Magnin in California. ‘You go into architecture to make the world a better place. A better place to live, to work, whatever. You don’t go into it as an ego trip.’ Frank Gehry, speaking in 2012 But he was an outsider by nature, and he began looking beyond the work of other architects for inspiration. Like many Angelenos, he was drawn to the laid-back, anything-goes atmosphere of the city, whose mix of garish mansions, flimsy bungalows, vacant lots, Googie’s coffee shops and colourful billboards was the antithesis of East Coast architectural academicism. And he became close to a generation of Los Angeles artists – Robert Irwin, Billy Al Bengston, Ed Moses, Larry Bell – whose surfboard-inspired aesthetic and raw work spaces suggested an alternative to the chilly austerity of late modernism and the reactionary tendencies of postmodernism.

“The artists were living in industrial buildings and warehouses,” Gehry said in the 2012 interview with the Times. “They were constantly moving things around – changing the rooms, building lofts or storage spaces. It was so free and unselfconscious. I wanted to do that.” In the late 1960s, Gehry and his wife divorced, and in 1975, he married Berta Aguilera. She survives him, along with their two sons, Sam, an architectural designer, and Alejandro, an artist; a daughter, Brina Gehry, from his previous marriage; and his sister, Doreen Gehry Nelson. Another daughter from his first marriage, Leslie Gehry Brenner, died in 2008. Gehry’s approach to his own Santa Monica home divided critics – and his neighbours. Credit: wikipedia.org The Gehrys bought their Santa Monica house, a two-story pink-stucco affair, in 1977. At Aguilera’s prodding, he began to tear it apart. The house’s rough, unfinished appearance attracted the attention of architecture critics, even as it infuriated neighbours. But its tormented forms – suggesting a world that had been ripped up and gently pieced back together – had their own kind of beauty. And the use of crude, everyday materials was Gehry’s assertion that the working-class aesthetic he had grown up with could be as appealing as anything found in the more refined corners of the city.

Decades later, he and Aguilera moved out of the little house that had first brought him fame and into a more luxurious spread overlooking Santa Monica Canyon. Designed with his son Sam, the new house was a sprawling, sometimes awkward composition of angled, heavy-timber posts and beams. Nonetheless, it retained some of the rough-and-tumble qualities of Gehry’s earlier architecture, and its jostling forms reflected a lifelong quest for emotional and creative freedom. Gehry kept on working. An interior view of Gehry’s Luma Foundation building in Arles, France. Credit: Getty Images In 2017, he completed the Pierre Boulez Hall in Berlin, designed in collaboration with conductor Daniel Barenboim: a compact, box-like space with a sunken floor and a floating elliptical balcony, contained inside an austere neo-classical building from the 1950s. And in 2021, the Luma Foundation building in Arles, in southern France, was finished; a twisting tower of stainless-steel bricks, it was inspired, in part, by the rocky terrain of the nearby Alpilles mountain range. At his death, Gehry was completing several projects for luxury goods magnate Bernard Arnault, including an 7618-square-metre flagship store for Louis Vuitton in Beverly Hills, California, and, in Paris, the conversion of an abandoned 1960s building into an exhibition space and events hall down the block from Arnault’s Fondation Louis Vuitton building. He was also putting the final touches on a 1000-seat concert hall for the Colburn School of Music, near his Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles.

title: Historic win: Vast Indigenous cultural landscape gains protection
text:
A 33,000-square-kilometre expanse of land in south-west Queensland will be protected from major mining activity after federal Environment Minister Murray Watt placed the site of Indigenous significance on the National Heritage List.

Mithaka cultural landscape, which spans the Barcoo and Diamantina shires, has gained interest as the site of the East Lake Eyre Trade Route, believed to be the most extensive Indigenous trade and exchange network.

The area has multiple well-preserved sites, including quarries, standing gunyahs (homes), and stone arrangements. One of these quarries is the largest in the world created by a pre-agriculture society, and two of the housing structures date back to 1770 and 1787.

An aerial view of Mithaka quarries, one of which is the largest in the world created by a pre-agriculture society.

The site’s inclusion on the National Heritage List means anyone planning to carry out activities in the area will need a self-assessment of whether it could significantly impact the listed value of the area. This generally does not include day-to-day pastoral activities.

title: ‘Truly terrified’: Queensland Ballet dancers issue on-stage plea for funding

“Despite over 60 years of success and the tireless efforts of our leadership team, we remain significantly underfunded compared to our industry peers,” Swan said, backed by the company’s dancers on the Lyric Theatre stage at the Queensland Performing Arts Centre.

In 2026, only two Queensland Ballet dancers will earn above the average wage, and 12 will be on the minimum wage. Credit: Angharad Gladding

title: Virginia Giuffre’s family asks: ‘Where are her missing millions?’
text:
Virginia Giuffre’s family members have raised questions over a “significant amount of missing money” in the ongoing row over what is believed to be her multimillion-dollar estate.

Giuffre, who was 41 when she died in Western Australia in April, is thought to have amassed an estimated $US22 million ($33.1 million) fortune through victim compensation funds and civil lawsuit settlements relating to the years of abuse she suffered at the hands of the late American financier Jeffrey Epstein.

Virginia Giuffre’s brother, Sky Roberts, has long challenged his brother-in-law’s right to inherit her money. Credit: Leigh Vogel for Sydney Morning Herald

This includes an estimated $US12 million payment she received from Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, the former Prince Andrew, to settle a sexual abuse claim brought against him in 2022. Andrew has always vehemently denied any wrongdoing.

However, court documents filed in the legal battle over her estate in Australia on Friday value it at just $472,000 – a legal threshold that dictates how assets in Australia are divided when there is no will. It may increase when more assets are discovered.

title: Why would anybody want to be an independent director at the Tigers?
text:
Loading Wests Tigers Rugby League Football Club Pty Ltd is a voting member of ARLC and a licensee of the NRL, entitling it to participate in the NRL competition. Wests Tigers first participated under that licence in 2000. Before that time, there were the Balmain Tigers and the Western Suburbs Magpies; creatures hardly known for living in harmony in the wild. Each is a foundation rugby league club with a storied history. Wests Tigers’ membership of ARLC, and its licence agreement tethering it to the NRL, are interdependent - if the licence agreement is axed, the membership of ARLC cuts out too, and vice versa. Wests Tigers is a company with two shareholders: Balmain Tigers Rugby League Football Club Limited, and Wests Magpies Pty Limited. But this is where things unravel.

The internal governance of Wests Tigers isn’t a democracy, or anything close to it. Balmain holds 1,000,020 Class A ordinary shares in Wests Tigers; Wests Magpies holds quadruple that number. Wests Magpies owns 80 per cent of the total share equity and voting rights in Wests Tigers. But it wasn’t always that way, as you discover once you examine the history books (and the ASIC registers). Back in the simpler times of 1999, when the Magpies/Tigers arranged marriage was forged – with the spectre of extinction hovering – the union at least was an equal one. No more. Sustained financial calamities, striking with dreadful regularity throughout the last quarter-century, have manifested in the renegotiation of arrangements and the destruction of any semblance of balance in what’s now a husk of a “joint” venture.

The control of the Balmain and Wests Magpies shareholders is curiouser still. Balmain’s governance is unremarkable in a sporting club sense; the company is in the control of its members. Wests Magpies is fundamentally different. It has two shareholders: Western Suburbs Leagues Club Limited and Western Suburbs District Rugby League Football Club Limited. There’s three shares on issue in Wests Magpies: an A Class share, a B Class share and a C Class. Wests Leagues holds the A Class and B Class shares, Wests Football holds the C Class, but Wests Leagues exerts control over Wests Football regardless. Complicated, much? Wests Tigers is supposed to be governed by a nine-person board that includes “independent” directors. The concept of being a member of a football club connotes having a democratic say in things. Conversely, that’s not really how the Wests Tigers structure operates. And it seems nobody really values any independent thinkers and doers there.

In line with the unequal shareholdings, Wests Magpies has the power to appoint many more directors to Wests Tigers than Balmain can. But a different problem exists, in terms of how Wests Magpies itself makes decisions. West Magpies is a registered club, governed by both the Corporations Act and the Registered Clubs Act. The latter legislation prescribes the classes of members a registered club can have, and other internal governance rules. Like most registered clubs, there’s thousands of members. But a bizarre quirk of the Wests Magpies structure, is that the majority of power rests with a cohort of 20 “debenture” holders, who’ve (apparently) lent the club $100 at an interest rate of six per cent, in consideration for enjoying entry into the inner cabal that effectively controls Wests Magpies in terms of director appointments. It’s those 20 lenders, who control four-fifths of the voting strength of Wests Tigers, and the NRL franchise itself. Democratic? Hardly. But there are other issues here as well. Clause 47.1 of the Wests Tigers constitution says the company shall have a maximum of nine directors.

Loading The appointment, removal and replacement of the directors is to occur in accordance with the company’s shareholder agreement and other instruments. The word “independent” is used no less than 55 times across the Wests Tigers’ constitution and shareholders agreement. There’s even an entire schedule that defines what the term means. Clause 4.11(g)(ii) of the shareholders agreement, governing the relationship between the Wests Tigers’ shareholders, casts material doubt on whether shareholders (not just Wests Magpies) can effectively give notice to remove an “independent director” as classified by the documents. Clause 4.11(g)(i) permits a shareholder who appointed a non-independent director to remove that director. Clause 4.11(g)(ii) requires notice from both shareholders AND National Rugby League Limited, to remove an independent director.

Which then leads to this question: which of Charlie Viola, Michelle McDowell, Annabelle Williams and Barry O’Farrell are the “independent directors” for the purpose of the Wests

Tigers governance documents? Those documents, in places, contemplate there being two independent directors. If there are only two directors of the four that, by proper definition, are the “independent directors”, legal questions exist about the proper basis for Wests Magpies’ belief that it, as the majority shareholder, can act alone. Wests Tigers CEO Shane Richardson. Credit: Oscar Colman Those questions need answers, before the Wests Tigers descend further. Whether O’Farrell or anyone else would bother torching money seeking Supreme Court injunctions about this stuff is hypothetical – who’d want to risk further damage to their reputation by seeking to stay in the tent? But assuming that Wests Magpies can issue a notice to remove an independent director, where that notice has proper legal effect, that then leads back to the fundamental question as to why anyone would want to be an independent director at all.
